ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to analyze the properties of transition metal complexes
Transition metal electron count, symmetry fluency, ligand metal interactions, orbital splitting geometry
My understanding of the fundamental concepts of inorganic chemistry improved.
Different types of ligands and their properties
I learned about different properties of transition metal complexes and their impact on reactivity.

Learned how to predict geometry and d orbital splitting for transition metal complexes.
Learned how to determine point symmetry groups for transition metal complexes.
Learned how to predict reactivity of transition metal complexes. 
Learned how to search for transition metal complexes in databases.
A better understanding of various aspects of transition metal chemistrygeometry and MOs, hard/soft acid base theory, chelation, and

The course covers the concepts of transition metal complexes such as: oxidation states, ligand classification, symmetry, d-splitting and spin, trends in different types of complexes, and design of ligands and TM complexes.
I learned a lot about metal and ligand properties. It was very interesting to learn more about a topic I only had very basic instruction on.
I got better understanding of orbital splitting

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I liked how the final project was open ended, so that we could design a complex for the area of research that interested us 

I also liked the break out discussions, as it allowed me to meet and get to know my classmates
Its got good flow, the final requirements are a bit much, I would prefer two more psets and a project rather than a final exam and project
Professor Holland makes the class engaging through interactive lectures, group work, and pre-lecture videos. We manage to learn a lot in just a few weeks.

Strength: interactive activities during class
Weakness: since the ligand development was a huge part of the criteria, i think more emphasis on the ligand should have enforced earlier part of the semester than the latter.
I think some of the concepts at the earlier part of the classes lacked explanation.
I like how there was a mix of lecturing and class discussion /group work
Lectures were pretty well organized. However, presentation of certain course concepts was not clear. In addition, course did not go much deeper into material than undergradute inorganic chemistry.

A strength of this course is that it covers a range of useful topics, and provides many specific examples from the literature. A weakness of this course is that it jumps into high level material too quickly, with unclear expectations for what is supposed to be known prior vs. what is supposed to be learned during the course.

Class was well organized and I always appreciated the opportunities to practice what we were learning in class and immediately get feedback. There were a couple classes where it felt more as though we were talking about case studies then broader principles; thats not a problem, but I wish those classes had been framed more in that way.

Professor Pat Holland is a very engaging lecturer. He was definitely the major strength of the course. Even when I was not particularly invested in some topics, I appreciated the way they were presented and the discussion questions posed during class. I cannot think of major weaknesses.

There was a lot of work associated with the course which made sure that you demonstrated learning on the topic, but it was a lot to accomplish with other grad classes at the same time. It would have been helpful to have more detailed notes/links to resources to fill in the gap necessary to complete assignments.

The strength of the course lay in the professor's consistent preparedness and willingness to address questions in class.

As for the weaknesses, the professor failed to establish clear boundaries between grades and selectively graded students at the end of the semester. He took an advantage of 'fuzzy boundaries,' enabling him to grade students individually as he pleased rather than adhering to a clear standard. For instance, Student X completed the course with a total of 89% and received an A, while Student Y completed the course with 90% or more and received a B. This treatment reflects bias, leading to unfair and discriminatory grading. Additionally, the professor's email responses displayed a somewhat passive-aggressive tone, attacking and belittling the student. Furthermore, the professor posted a statement on the Canvas website after the final exam, specifying that an A would be 'roughly 90%', and a B would be 'roughly 80%.' It appears that the professor did not consistently follow these numerical guidelines, indicating a biased and possibly personal approach to grading. Such actions represent a clear violation of equitable assessment standards that should have never happened at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
Yes, Pat knows how to teach very well. This course will set u right for inorganic chem.
If you're interested in the concepts and problem solving involved in inorganic chemistry, then absolutely.
I wouldnt recommend this course unless they are interested in bioinorganic or ligand design
Yes
I would only recommend this course to is highly interested in inorganic chemistry, and has a lot of prior experience with the topic.
Yes. I wish I had more time to put into the class; the end sneaks up on you and it is easy to have conceptual misunderstandings without realizing it until its too late.
I would recommend this course for people interested in inorganic chemistry and/or organometallic chemistry.
Yes, I think it is a great class for advanced chemists who may have not seen the material before.
